reviewText:
One of the better examples of why indy developers should be allowed to exist, unfortunately several flaws in this game prevent recommendation.

Technically, the game has limited resolution modes and generally doesn't behave like a PC game.  Being unaware of foreground windowing prevents foreground switching and causes the game to crash... that's ok, developers probably weren't aware that DirectX 3.0 was introduced in 1997, so it's understandable they wouldn't have bothered to test the game under Windows.

Artwork is 3D which at least beats going 2D platformer, but it's still extremely low effort.

Gameplay quickly becomes stale and repetitive, which is the only chance the developers had in way of apology for their negligence on the artwork and on making the game compatible with Windows.

Simply too hard to approve.

Quick Summary: Costume Quest is a “children’s” RPG focused more on story than on graphics or complexity. The actual gameplay reminds me of a simplified Chrono Trigger or similar Japanese RPG where you travel the map with semi random encounters and fight by taking turns exchanging attacks with the enemy.

I called it a children’s RPG, by which I mean not only is the story about a group of kids (even the main bad guy is a child) but the story would be considered PG if it were a movie. You control a group of kids teamed up on Halloween to stop monsters from stealing all the candy, using the power of your Halloween costumes. In the main world you look like a bunch of kids in homemade costumes, but when you encounter enemies and enter battle, you become whatever you’re dressed as. For example some of the costumes are robot, jack o’ lantern, or unicorn. Outside of battle you’re free to change your team’s costumes to whatever you have unlocked, and some costumes have some sort of real world effect (for example the robot allows you to run fast).

When your team is in battle, the options are extremely limited. You can either run away, attack, or use a special move. The special move is unlocked every few combat rounds and usually it’s something like a big attack or a healing spell for your team. An added combat mechanic is the ability to boost your attack or weaken the enemy attack by doing an easy quicktime event. For example every time you attack you press the correct button in time and your attack does 10% more damage, or you press it at the right time during the enemy attack and only take 90% normal damage.

Pros:
+Decent cutesy, fun story for kids. Nothing a parent would have to worry about.
+Very simplified gameplay, with some element of skill in boosting attacks or finding hidden items in the world.
+The DLC Grubbins on Ice is included and adds a few hours more gameplay.

Cons:
-Kind of a childish game, but you knew what you were getting into.

Overall the game is a nice diversion that you can finish in a few days. I only played it at first because when Steam was releasing their trading cards, this was the one of the first games I owned with cards and I figured I’d give it a try while waiting for cards to drop. It was not disappointing.

I liked the theme for this game. It did a great job on showing what it was like to celebrate Halloween as kids. There are a lot of collectables, but the only ones you can use are the costumes and battle stamps. The combat is very basic for a RPG. You have 1 normal attack and 1 special attack. No items, spells, or anything else. The only things you can influence the battle with is what costume you pick and stamp you have equipped. It is also one of the easiest RPGs ever made. I never got a game over and 1 of my characters might of died twice in the whole game.The game lasts about 7 hours; including the free DLC that comes with the game.

reviewText:
Costume Quest is a cute little casual game with a great sense of humor. Although the gameplay is very simplistic and the fighting system is fairly boring the short game length and funny dialog makes it forgivable.

The game starts you as an aspiring trick or treater. Unfortunately disaster strikes when your sibling is abducted by goblins and you have to go rescue him/her. The game plays quite simply, you have to goto various house to trick and treat which gives you candy, the game's currency. You battle goblins and other monsters as you go along and through completion various quests you unlock new costumes.

The combat plays quite simple. Yourself and 2 companions go into battle each wielding a costume that will grant them different powers and you then take turns attacking the enemies until one side is killed off. Each costume has only one regular attack and one special move they can perform every three turns but to try and break up the monotone a little each attack requires you to perform a quicktime event to maximize your damage.

The graphics are fairly simple but the style is sharp and the locations have a great Halloween look to them which really helps. The sound and music is nothing impressive but it doesn't detract anything from the experience either.

All in all it's a cute little that gives you a few hours of fun however the simple gameplay and short length means it's only worth getting as a bargain title.

reviewText: I highly recommend this as a childrens game. It plays like a really simple stripped down JRPG, just set around halloween instead of around the coming of the great big evil that wipes out the world. If you've already gotten a few RPGs under your belt you'll likely be bored out of your mind, but as I said a great my first JPRG" for kids around 8-12 yrs old."

reviewText: Gotta thank one of my besties, gogostar, for getting me this game. Because of it, I love Double Fine Productions and will definitely be keeping an eye out for future projects. It's supposed to be a children's turn-based RPG but only informed teens and adults would understand some of the more subtle humor. I couldn't help but be reminded of The Nightmare Before Christmas (you even get to battle as a Jack Skellington-like pumpkin) but less deranged. If you're looking for difficult, intricate gameplay, this isn't your game. It's got a lot of charm, funny dialogue, good feels, nice art style, and it's adorable as ♥♥♥♥. What other game would let you duke it out as a vampire, unicorn, and a pirate (my favorite in-game trio)? Definitely recommended for anyone who wants to relax with a nice, cute story about sibling bonding and friendship.

reviewText:
This is an adorable take on the standard turn-based RPG. As sweet as its subject matter, Costume Quest puts you in the shoes of a fourth grader who is tasked with rescuing his (or her) sibling from the clutches of a villainess whose evil schemes is going to wreck Halloween.

The game features standard RPG fare such as leveling up, hit points, and turn-based combat. Instead of classes you don costumes which grant you special powers, which can be augmented with special battle stickers.

I loved the art style, the humor, and the fact that I have a game about trick or treating. My only quibble was that combat was too easy, with the exception of the final boss in Grubbins on Ice, I don't think I lost a single battle. But this is probably due to enemies not respawning. So, instead of a standard JRPG where you're forced to level grind for hours against a never ending horde of enemies, you need to discover the perfect balance of costumes and battle stickers amongst your party to succeed. In this regard, I feel that Costume Quest is a very newbie friendly RPG.

reviewText:
This game features some big problems. The biggest two being there is no map screen, and the battle system is so stupidly simple, it's actually pretty offensive.

Map screen however, is the biggest issue with this game. The neighborhood is LARGE, and is VERY easy to get lost in. With no easily accessible way to see where you're going, it's too easy to get lost in. Do you need to make it so that objectives are on the map? No. But a way should be included so you can at least figure out where you currently are, and where you have already explored.

The Battle System litterally consists of 2 buttons... A basic attack and an ultimate attack. That's it. There's no strategy, no extra abilities, nothing.

The story is at least interesting and the graphics are pretty good.

If you're an older gamer, I would stay far away from this. There's nothing there for you. However, if you have a younger gamer you'd like to introduce to the RPG genre, this would be a good game for them.

reviewText:
I've first played Brutal Legend, and now Costume Quest. Once again, Double Fine leaves me with mixed feelings.
Costume Quest seems to be the kind of game I would enjoy a lot when I was a kid!
Essencially, you're Reynolds, and it's Halloween. In the midst of trick-or-treating, there are monsters, stealing all the candy, who ended up kidnapping your sister.
So, you put on your most badass costume and go look for her, fighting the monsters with the aid of your costume's powers, along with some friends you meet along the way.
That sounds like something I would enjoy immensively when I was younger! And I still enjoyed it today, but it's not quite my kind of game.


The game is a mixture of an adventure/platformer game, with a JRPG(ish) type combat.
In combat, each character has a normal attack and a special attack, which takes turns to recharge. Instead of simply choosing which attack you want, there's also a QTE event that you have to do in order to boost your normal attacks.
Each costume the character wears influences their attacks, and have a very unique style to them.
There are also stickers you can collect while exploring the world, which will then give you a passive or active ability in battle.
You have from 1 to 3 characters, and the same with the enemies. Each team has their attack turn, until the battle is finished.

I didn't find the combat system very deep, with the exception of the Boss fights, which sometimes required a certain ability to be beaten, making the player experiment with the different costumes until he beat it. That was cool, but other than that, it felt a bit too shallow.
To its favor thought, animation was top-notch, and every attack made you feel like a badass doing it.

Outside of combat, you go around collecting candy, sometimes from door to door, other times just in the environment. You also interact with NPCs, with a very DoubleFine-esque dialogue which is always welcome. You have 4 zones (3 in the main game, 1 in the DLC), each with its theme, and a group of side quests. These side quests help the player explore the world, and also provide rewards. I didn't find them particularly interesting, but they were on the way, so it did not detract from the experience. I just think they could have done something more with those sidequests.
There are quite a few secrets" and Easter Eggs hidden around

reviewText: Costume Quest is a classic RPG with turn-based combat mixed with Double Fine style. You play a child out on halloween teaming up with other kids and fighting monsters, all while trick-or-treating.  Instead of the usual RPG equipment, the halloween costumes you wear transform into full size versions during combat, providing their associated powers to your characters.  It all meshes together perfectly, as you would expect from a Double Fine game.\n\nI'm not sure what else there is to say.  It's cute, charming, and a solid RPG experience that doesn't feel dull and repetitive like many of these types of RPGs do.  My only complaints are that the controls are a bit sluggish and the game is locked at 30 fps which will hopefully be addressed in a patch now that Double Fine has the rights to the game back.

reviewText:
So before I start, THIS GAME IS MEANT FOR CHILDREN!! And I'm recommending it on that behalf, If you are a hardcore gamer THIS GAME ISN'T FOR YOU.

Story (8/10)
The story isn't bad for a children game, but it's a bit lame for older audience. A kid saves his sibling on Halloween night. a bit long and unrealistic (for one night), but it's fiction, so who cares.
As an adult I liked the story at the beginning, but for a game meant for children it wasn't that simply put and the lack of audio narration makes a barrier between the child and the story.

Sounds (6/10)
This is one of the worst aspects of the game, and the reason for that is the lack of narration or sounding for the characters.
In a game heavily based on story with a lot of dialogues, FOR CHILDREN I think that is a huge problem. What takes me 7 secs to read might take a child 1-2 mins to read, and that's a deal breaker.
Other than that, the game has good in-game music, and atmospheric music when entering some danger zones made a good time for me, and I think will more for a child.

Graphics (8/10)
For a casual children game, the graphics are very good, I won't say they are mind blowing ones, but they are colourful enough to catch children's eyes, and decent enough for this type of games.

Gameplay (8.5/10)
I think the most interesting aspect of thi game -for children- is the gameplay. It's way complicated than the ordinary children game, but it's way simpler than a MOBA or RPG. I think this game might be a nice introduction for children to use controller (I haven't used one to test it to be honest). Also there's a lot of side objectives those are pretty interesting and the different interactions between different costumes (although it's not that great of a deal) may be one of the most challenging aspects for children.
If I have a kid and I want him/her to start hardcore gaming this is where I might start.
BUT... it's so repetitive in fights that for a hardcore gamer it'll be extremely lame. so be aware of that.

Overall (7.8/10)
If you are getting this game for a kid, I think it's a good gift, just be aware of the repetitiveness of it. And the kid may suffer because of the dialogue if the kid reads slowly. Other than that, the game is good. It has sequel that I haven't played so I don't know how much it has improved, but I hope they have fixed the issues I mentioned.
I'll definitly recommend it for a child.

P.S. I say this again... If you are hardcore gamer that only enjoys AAA games you shouldn't even consider this one....

reviewText: If you're a fan of RPG's and Halloween, then this game is a must play. I played and beat this back when it was released on PS3. In spirit of this year's Halloween, I decided to play it again. I was surprised that the expansion campaign was added for FREE, kudos. This isn't some complex RPG, but merely an ode to when we were kids. Imagine how a kid feels and sees the world when he's wearing a cardboard robot costume, only to transform into a huge robot in battle that can fire missles! It's a cute idea and implemented well. That combat system is very simple, but it'll keep your attention since you need to complete various tasks such as press button X" at the correct time. Small sense of accomplishment when you finally gather all the materials for a new costume and test out their special attacks. Took me about 8 hours to complete

reviewText:
Costume Quest is a charming, heart-warming, hilarious, and well-crafted game. It is a nice little semi-RPG romp that can be completed in about 5 hours. The graphical style is extremely pretty and atmospheric. The sounds and music conjure up whimsical spookiness. The writing and story is superb, always giving a laugh yet pushing you forward.

The gameplay consists of fun exploration around locales, attempting to trick-or-treat and also find all the secrets. There is also a fun but simple JRPG turn-based battle system implemented with wonderful “epic” battles on gorgeous set pieces.

The only downside to speak of is that much of the dialogue automatically forwards itself, resulting in many missed lines unless you are a speed reader. Also, none of the dialogue is voiced, but that is only an issue because of how easy it is to miss certain lines.

Overall, the game so perfectly captures the spirit of youthful exuberance and the pursuit of much candy! I highly recommend this game to anyone who wants a fun, charming, and memorable experience!

reviewText:
An amazingly cute turn-base rpg with charming designs
This game is just to cute that it deservs a lawsuit, my heart almost melted of joy, not just for its charming level design, but for the storyline too.
The story is pretty much about two brothers(twins) that only want to have THE best halloween of their lives by filling their little baskets with treats, sadly they stumb upon a candy theft operation set by a witch and her group of creeps who wants to steal all the candies to feed an evil lord, so she can be granted passage to their world.
But an halloween wouldn´t be an halloween without good old Trick or Treat right?
In this game, you dont just fight monsters, you are also able to knock doors and say the magic word for some extra sweets, but what i really REALLY love in this game is the dialogs, its funny and just adorable, also these kids have some balls, i remember being scared of monsters and adults in my childhood, but these kids face danger head on with cute foul languages, its funny to see them pick on each other.
Definitely a must buy if you´re into turn-based, RPG or just down cute adventure games, i promise you wont regret it.
Money well spend.

reviewText: 8.5/10\n\nCostume Quest is a perfect game for friends and family to play on Halloween! The gameplay is smooth, graphics are clean, and the sound effects are pretty good too. Even if I had paid full price for the game, $10 is pretty cheap for that much entertainment. Great job Double Fine Productions.

reviewText:
This is essentially a casual RPG for kids, but I'm reviewing it anyway as an adult.

Costume Quest is a very short turn-based RPG, but the highlight of its features are what it doesn't have. It's devoid of pretty much any interesting game system. The slim turn-based combat system present is similar to the Final Fantasy games, but you'll get more depth out of Final Fantasy games or 99% of their copycats. All of the combat uses Quick Time Events as well, which gets old after the second or third combat encounter. Game balance is simple and a little skewed. The game can be difficult (but hardly) when you only have two party members, and its trivially easy once you have three.

The overworld is linear. There's a tiny bit of exploration to be had, but not much. There are roughly four quests in the entire game, each repeated several times for each phase of the game: find a card off a monster (combat encounters), bob for apples (simple mini-game), trick or treat houses (random combat encounters), and find six hiding kids (semi-hidden on overworld).

The game crashed a few times, and since there is no manual save feature at any time, I lost 15-20 minutes of progress each time. The game plays the same every time.

There are costumes to get, which are your battle suits or classes". Variation here is only relevant in the costume's "special ability" but the game is so easy that once you have three party members
hoursPlayed: witty dialogue is OK but not astounding. No voice acting.\n\nI don't recommend this game. You can find much better games in all of its genres for cheaper.  If you insist on wanting it
voteText: it's worth $2-3 on a sale perhaps. My playtime says 16 hours but that included a long idling session by accident. It's a 5-7 hour game.\n\nI'm surprised this game has a sequel. It's popularity seems dependent on the Double Fine brand
helpfulPercent: which hasn't been the same for me since Spacebase DF and the Broken Age Kickstarter mishandlings."

reviewText: I usually try to stay away from stuff that is cute and kidsy, but this game is actually not really like that. It is a charming little game with really great graphic design and a good turn based rpg combat system like Final Fantasy style. You go around a town map doing quests and it is so far a lot of fun. Double Fine ♥♥♥♥ed up Iron Brigade bad which was really unfortunate, but they have a gem on their hands here with this game. The huge flaws in this game though is that it is very short (I beat the main game + the dlc in 7 hours), there is no replay value: once you beat it there is no reason to ever play it again, and it could also be more difficult. One of my favorite short playthroughs that I have played in a long time. I don't know why exactly but it just strikes a chord with me and I love it. I think because it reminds me of one of my favorite games of all time, Earthbound on the Super Nintendo. A very good game, just way too short. Catch it on sale and only on sale.

reviewText:
Although Halloween have passed this is game that must be played, and would say going to 'trick or treat' would be funny and challenger. So Costume Quest is a Action RPG with a nice concept on it.

As you guys already figure it this game takes place on Halloween, where two siblings, Reynold and Wren, will go ask for candies. The player at this point will choose which sibling to play as. One of the siblings will be kidnapped - depend what siblings you choose - and our missions is to find out her he/she is. During our mission, we will make some quest, and personally this was the worst part for me, because the quest are always the same. Costume Quest has 3 levels, the neighborhood, the mall and a carnival, and on all level the quest are the same, go ask for candy, do eat apple game, find some cards, get the costumes, find kids playing hide-and-seek, same thing happens on the DLC despite the level design is different.

But if you put that behind your backs the game is really enjoyable, the game's graphics are a cartoonish style - thing that i love - and are well designed and very colorful, Costume Quest is more than colorful, is nice piece of art! The neighborhood and the others locations can make ous dive on feeling, is like we are on Halloween. And since is a Halloween Theme we will have lot of costumes to wear.

Now to get the costumes you need to, get three different materials. When we get the costumes, besides changing our appearance we can go through places we didn't can before and will also gives special skills to use in battles. This battles can arise in two different ways, when you are searching for candy's or on street when you find a troll. When such things happens the scenario will completely change and your suit power will be activated, the battle style is a turn-based + quick time events.  When you do three attacks you will have a change to make the special attack, that can be a offensive or defense move. The special attack will be different according to the suit you are wearing.

Since this is a RPG make sence we get XP for doing things, well when you complete the quest, defeat the trolls you will get some XP that will raise your level as well your defenses and your attack. Besides, you can buy in-game booster to help raise your attack and defense, although this is not very important because your enemies don't give a strong fight.

Although this is a soundless game, contains a decent amount of humor there, some nice jokes and the dialogues between the characters is funny to read too. Costume Quest really grabbed me from the moment i installed, so is totally recommend!

~ 8/10

reviewText:
Such a charming game. The graphics are cute and, even though the gameplay is the same as pretty much all the other RPGs, it still feels refreshing. Why ? Because most of the battles are based on trick-or-treating. And the gear you can collect are Halloween costumes. It's a cool idea, I really enjoyed it. But it does get repetitive near the end (it's about 5 hours long); the quests are the same in every new area. Apple bobbing, card collecting, finding hidden kids. It's a great game, but I just wish there was more variation.
Still, if you love RPGs, or charming games in general, this is a must play.

[Rating: 86/100]

reviewText: Costume Quest is a charming, fun take on the turn based RPG genre. Sort of condensed. Instead of individually swapping weapons, spells, attacks, and actions you choose costumes that change your appearance, battle abilities and attacks, and help solve free roam puzzles with various actions. On top of that you can choose one additional action or buff for each character and swap them as you choose. Instead of finding and swapping party members you can instead choose their costumes. It really is sort of a My First RPG"
date: which may sound dull to an adult but it works well enough to engage. My one issue with this system is that there wasn't enough difference between the costumes to incentivise change. You are forced to change to solve some puzzles but I would always switch back before a battle. The battle system is turned based and pretty simple with only a few options each turn. This style lends itself to a little repetition but I tended to enjoy them since they typically don't drag on. One twist (Maybe
recommended: I don't play a lot of turn based RPGs) is that to land more powerful attacks you have to complete a QTE. There are several variations but each attack only has one. Things like press at a certain time
voteText: or repeatedly tap a button. Personally I didn't find that it detracted from the experience and actually makes sure you're paying attention to the battle and lets you contribute in some way. In true Double Fine fashion the writing (literally because there is no voice acting. Not a problem
helpfulPercent: just a statement) is top notch. Funny
votesHelpful: witty
votesTotal: and endearing with jokes for both adults and children. Don't write off Costume Quest because of its apparently juvenile theme
votesFunny: you'd be missing out. It's fun
commentsCount: funny
column16: and really is a nice departure from what you've probably played last. It doesn't over stay it's welcome and is well worth your time."

Gameplay is repetitive, the battles are boring and the only real thing (other than graphics) saving the game is the battle stamps you can use to add effects.\n\nI also ran into the game breaking bug in the fry quest where the solution from TS was to restart because they don't plan a fix. Well, it left a bad taste in my mouth that a major game breaking bug is known and nothing was attempted to fix it. I am not sure why anyone would want to replay this whole thing and risk running into the bug again.

reviewText:
You should've bought it once you saw the developers were Double Fine productions. Seriously. C'mon man. Purchase it already.

Oh, you need convincing? Think of the best halloween of your life. Now take that, shove that memory in the back of your head, and replace it with this game. It's halloween gone right, and by that, I mean, you wear costumes WHICH TURN INTO MONSTER SLAYING MACHINES. The RPG system doesn't have depth past a general level and choosing your party's costume compostion. Each costume brings a special skill which helps turn the tide of battle to your favor. It is a turned based battle system, and all the battles rely on your tactics moreso than if you grinded up stats to beat something. The game is charming, and the mechanics seem simple, but the beauty of that simplicity is that this game tests your skill and not your propensity to grind on enemies in an RPG.

F...ING MONSTER SLAYING MACHINES

reviewText:
I don't want to hate on this game. I love the story. I love the characters. I love the dialogue. I love the art style.

I hate grindy JRPG combat.

Where 75% of your game time is spent in combat, it should be engaging; not a throwback to the NES era. After my fourth fight, I found myself avoiding enemies whenever possible. Not because of the difficulty, but because each fight is another 2-3 minute delay from that quest item that I was looking for in the game world. I challenge anyone to convince me that this style of combat makes the game fun.

If there were a quarter as many enemies, and you used puzzle-solving to overcome them, this game would gel a lot better.

reviewText: Simply a short cute little game.  The art style is great, the story and characters are fun and the unlockables are simple enough to collect but still rewarding to find.  The game is not without its shortcomings though, the fights really started to feel repetitive around half way though the game and by the end I was starting to dread the idea of another fight sequence.  However, because the game is short (~5 to 7 hours) and fighting is not a huge part of the game, this is not the huge drawback it would be for a longer more serious game.\n\nIn the end I plan on making this game a halloween tradition, it is cute and fun, and I would recommend this game.

reviewText: This one was a surprise. When looking at some pictures, I wasn't expecting much, but was surprised by it. This game has what you can expect from Double Fine, very funny and well written dialogue, fun combat system and a nice world to explore. The biggest flaw of this game, is it's length and scope. It's a short game. But the 6-8 hours it will take you to complete it, will be fully enjoyed. The story, although quite simplistic, is fun and entertaining. The combat system is  very nice, it's a JRPG turn based system with some quick time events thrown in between. When you enter battle, you'll transform into the costume you're wearing, so if you're using a cardboard robot costume, in battle you turn into a full laser shooting robot. The game has a lot of costumes and all of them very different from each other so you'll have to consider what costumes are best for each character and each situation. To add even more diversity, you have battle stamps to collect and use. These give some additional passive abilities, and make a lot of difference in combat. The game has a very simple level system and currency (candy). You can use candy to buy some upgrades and stamps to further develop your character. All in all, this is a very good bur short RPG, and I recommend it to everyone who likes the genre.

reviewText: I recently went back through the games I picked up this year, but didn't really spend any time with so far. In doing this, I found two awesome gems. Both were by Double Fine. This isn't all that surprising, given their previous games. The first of these two is Costume Quest. I've thorougly enjoyed what I've played of it, and found the story to be compelling and fun. A 'hybrid' of tactical and story gaming, I've never seen it done like this. Set on any generic Halloween, it harkens back to the days of my youth, running from house to house begging for candy and living in an imaginary world of ghouls and ghosts.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Costume Quest is one of those unusual games you either love or hate. It is quite original, as is the trademark of Tim Schafer and the great Double Fine Productions, and offers a mixture of RPG and Adventure quite unseen in all the role-playing games I have played so far. A possible problem is that it merely brushes the surface of the genre and never goes in-depth. Don't expect neat level up and careful customization of your party, Costume Quest need to be played for the taste of its storyline, full of humor and for the cool gust it blows on a game market filled with clones.
I also continued to play this game for its atmosphere, despite the repetition and the boredom that may occur after the too many similar moments of gameplay: the combat system barely evolves throughout the (short) story and the items hunts sometimes break the rhythm.
To conclude, I would recommend it only to those who are ok with playing a game for its particular taste and the polish of its storyline rather than for the mechanics of its gameplay. Once again, Costume Quest is a very short game (I maxed it out in less than seven hours) but it is definitely a great pick for those who are looking for a bit share of originality .

reviewText: Costume Quest is an amusing, anime style, adventure game with some unique dynamics. Firstly, costumes you pick up become useful in the game world in two ways. One, they each have a unique ability, like the robot costume to boost your speed and let you jump off ramps, and secondly, they become genuine fighting equipment, changing your character into what the costume represents. Be it a knight, or a fancy big robot, the costumes have incredibly power in this fun and quirky game by the creators of Psychonauts. Definelty a fun little game to play, and a get a fresh taste of Double Fine on PC.

reviewText:
Gameplay-wise, Costume Quest is like a classic JRPG from the NES era. You control one kid you choose at the beginning of the game, between a brother and sister, the other accompanies you trick-or-treating throughout the neighborhood. You soon find yourself in an adventure, that spans the entire town and beyond. There are also some mini-games and side-quests you can play in order to improve your characters.
On the plus side, the game has nice graphics and a low hardware requirement. On the negative side, the game has no voice-over, meaning you have to read every dialogue, and sometimes I found it switching a bit fast. The controls aren't bad, but they are not great either, I needed some time to get used to them.
If you don't like quick time events, then you will not like Costume Quest, because combat features them. Succeeding will improve your action, while failing will have bad consequences (less damage done, more damage sustained).
All-in-all a nice game with good humor.

reviewText:
I dont recommend this game, however if you are younger or havent played a lot of RPGs then Costume Quest could be a good entry point to the genre.

The combat is really simple. You press a button and maybe time another button press or whatever on screen command is to do your one attack. After enough basic attacks you get a special move with a bigger effect. Thats it, each charecter can wear any costume in the game so there is slight variety but every costume boils down to the same strategy.

The mini games are nice at first. You trick or treat door to door and get either candy or a random encounter. There are children playing hide and seek to find. Stamps to collect new costumes to assemble. And theres bobbing for apples which is terrible. The biggest problem is that throught the levels you just play the same minigames over and over again. There may be some new puzzles each level but it always breaks down to the same basic thing.

I wouldnt say Costume Quest is bad, just merely mediocre. If youve played a lot of games then there isnt much here for you, as plenty of other games can acomplish the same thing in a much more satisfying way.

reviewText:
I like the idea for costume quest. The visional style fits very well with the game. The game has some fun characters too.

What I don't like with the game is that it is extremely repetitive. The first area you are in was pretty fun. But it feels like the game might as well has ended there. Because you then get to another area where you have basically the same quests again, just at a different location. The quests aren't very fun either. The combat is very repetitive because only have one normal attack and a special attack that you get after two attacks. So every fight is: regular attack which follows with a quick time event to get the maximum damage out of your attack, do this for every character. Then quick time event to reduce damage from the enemy. Then repeat this to get special attack, do special attack. if the enemy isn't dead do it again.

The concept for the game is very good. It could have been an awesome game. But sadly it's too repetitive and it kind of falls flat. Even though the game is very short is feels far to long for what the actual content of the game. It feels like they made the game longer by just using the same quest again with a new background texture.

reviewText:
This game is just fantastic! It's a fun little halloween RPG by the amazing team at Double Fine, which are responsible for masterpieces like Psychonauts and Brutal Legend.

This game does not disappoint at all. It's a short and sweet game that i enjoyed from start to finish, even though the combat can get a bit repetitive in the start of the game, Once you get out of the first area of the game the combat becomes fresh again. Introducing new enemies, new costumes, and new abilities.

It also has quite a bit of challenge, i didn't die a lot, but nearing the end of the game it really gets difficult.

Overall it's a really good game. 9/10

reviewText: Witty, dry, and full of good gameplay, Costume Quest portrays children as serious, intelligent creatures with a bit too much wisdom for their age. reviewText:
This review explains how Double Fine's Costume Quest is a shallow, repetitive, featureless example of the RPG adventure game genre.
[. . .] You do 1-3 identical attacks, then 1-3 identical dodges, and on every third turn special moves. That’s the only combat rhythm, and you’ll be doing it until every battle is a chore. There are no combos; no combat varieties; no difficult build decisions; no in-battle items; and, except for ‘go for the priest first,’ there is no strategy. [. . .]

reviewText:
Here is another beauty that I got thanks to that Double Fine humble bundle. Every time I start thinking of going back to console gaming these bundles and steam sales just drag me right back in the glorious world of PC gaming and the silly and serious experiences it has to offer.

Costume Quest is a game that I read and saw a decent amount of before I played it from the various videogame news sites that I follow. As a result I went into the game with a certain amount of expectations which were not entirely met if I am being honest.

Costume Quest is a pretty mediocre game. Its definitely not bad, but its not that good either. If you are hoping to find a game that can be used as an eight to ten hour distraction then you should be fine getting Costume Quest. If you want something that is more than a distraction then you need to look elsewhere. Because while this game has a lot of charm, its very superficial in some major parts of its design leaving the experience of playing this game feeling boring and repetitive in more than one instance. This is something I feel pretty strongly about, to that point that I'm not looking forward to the sequel that Double Fine recently announced. Unless there are some major changes being made to the gameplay aspect of the game which I don't think is going to happen to be honest.

If you feel like reading a more detailed review you can find it here: http://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2014/06/costume-quest.html.

reviewText: I feel like this game would have been much better without the level scaling. I absolutely detest level scaling. That noted, I also ♥♥♥♥ing loathe it when a game comes out with an expansion (in this case, Grubbins on Ice) that literally follows the same plot and storyline (someone gets captured, have to go save them, same costumes, etc) but just in a different location and differently dressed monsters. That's pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ in my honest opinion. Why you would try to make an exact clone of the last game and try to pass it off as dlc/expansion is unforgivable. Come on Double Fine, you're better than this.

reviewText: I have been enjoying Costume Quest a lot actually. The cartoon look is visually appealing and when you can play in 1080p it makes it even better. It is a quirky kind of RPG yet it does not fully present itself as an RPG, you can roam around and complete quest without even looking at your quest log. It's battles are fun and attacks involve timing and require you to think fast on which key to press when blocking attacks. I strongly recommend this game, worth its money, you may want to wait for a sale if you are money conservative.

reviewText:
This is a game for kids, not kids-at-heart. I'm an adult, that likes Halloween. I like dressing up in costumes, and both handing out and having candy. I try to host a Halloween party every year.

I got this game because I was hoping that there would be the same level of dialouge and characters as in Psychonauts. It's not.

It's a very, very simplistic game, with choose a button and some QTE stuff. The costumes change things a bit, but anyone who has played any RPG type games at all can probably figure out the two damage dealers, one healer, or one tank, one damage, one healer, and not ever really need to switch costumes, besides to look at the different attacks.

It's not a bad game for kids at all. The writing is still decent, and some of the jokes were amusing, but as an adult fan of Doublefine who purchased it for myself, I feel let down. It's also a very short game. Again, one that would more appeal to a kid audience.

There IS a market for more adult-based Halloween costume style games out there that don't need horror or sex. I just wish Doublefine had realized that.

reviewText: This is a really fantastic light RPG. It has that signature Double Fine dialog and in general the feel you expect from them. Just like I mentioned in my Stacking review this has reasonable achievements and very good accomodation for the completionist type. Appropriate since both this and Stacking was written in either 2 weeks or 4 weeks (I forgot the story) as part of a company creativity exercise.\n\nIt's really a shame that EA and LucasArts are such inept pieces of ♥♥♥♥ that they didn't capitalize on Double Fine during this period and allow them creative freedoms or the sequel to this would have came out much earlier and a Psychonauts sequel might actually exist. But oh well, great game overall and much of what I said about Stacking can be applied here. Double Fine knows you love to collect things and it knows that you love to 100% things, and they love you for loving those things and so accomodate you well.

reviewText:
costume quest is a pretty neat rpg done in the spirit of halloween.

i must say this is a great rpg for gamers new and old.
there is no item managing that hardcore rpg games have which means young and old both can enjoy this game without worry of having to run back to the store.

there is a store in game though which has battle cards with varying effects u can use equip each charecter with 1 card swappable outside of battle.  healing wise there is none other then in battle so no worrys of dieing from being unprepared.

one of the toughest parts about this game is prob the boss battles aside from that the trying to get every defense and attack perfect by pressing the right button.

also to talk about the battles pretty simple just attack and defend before the enemy hits you u try to press the correct button if hit the correct one critical attack and in defense better defense or a dodge and if right card equiped counter.

after 3 turns ur specials charged which they are pretty nice addition. but do not take the game lightly u can lose battles if ur not careful. but there is no such thing as gameover in this game it just places u in the area right before the battle <3

also to note there is a varity of costumes which u have to find the parts to make them each comes with a special ablity which is pretty neat. oh and there is special ablitys for some of them useable in the field which adds to the fun.

now if u like rpgs that arent that tough yet still fun give costume quest a go as its worth a play and i would say a replay <3   oh and did i mention candy? TONS OF CANDY!

so grab costume quest and help stop the evil witch and the monsters from stealing all of the candy before its too late and halloween is ruined!   ~ will be updating after finish the dlc quest grubbins on ice that came with :3


just finished the dlc grubbins on ice make sure u collect every costume before playing it and load same slot u finished in, as u will have all of the orignal costumes then ^w^ its like costume quest turned christmas quest. basicly the same gameplay new areas and new costumes and areas. also do note finish costume quest then the dlc as seems it leads into game 3 ^w^


if this review is not helpful, please leave a comment as to why u feel that way so i may make changes if needed ^w^

reviewText:
Boring, repetetive, shallow.

this is what the game is in general.

you will fight the same monsters over and over again,
you will use the exact same moves with the exact same characters over and over again
you will do the same minigames over and over again

there is very little customization and most of it is just extra stats, no items, no unlocking new abilities. only unlocking new classes called 'costumes' once in a while and each costume has only 2 abilities.

the story is simplistic, the graphics are unimpersive, the kids look cute sometimes but that's about it.

this is 100% kids game. unless you are buying this game for your 10 year old naphew don't bother. it's a waste of time.

a big shame such a wonderful company like doublefine created such a shallow and generic title

reviewText: First things first, I love this game. The graphics are adorable, the story is great, and then all of the costumes are really awesome to see in battle. I completely recommend this game to anyone who enjoys trick-or-treating or Halloween in general!
Picked this up in a humble bundle a while ago but am just getting down to actually playing it. The controls are a bit clunky initially, but overall it's been an extrememly enjoyable experience!
Breathtaking! My childhood halloween was never like this!!!

Costume Quest is a game with a great atmosphere and gameplay that, while being pretty broken (load up on stuns and you can't lose), is extremely enjoyable simply to experience everything.  It's definitely an easy game, but if you're in the mood to just relax and enjoy a childlike sense of wonder again then this is the game for you.

For me, Costume Quest is the archetypal current Double Fine game. It has a great idea, nice presentation, and tedious, repetitive gameplay where you do the same thing over and over again until the designers thought it was long enough to satisfy the minimum game length people want. SomehowCostume Quest manages to distill and concentrate the absolute worst elements of JRPG design into a seemingly endless grind mitigated a little by the cute plot and presentation.

The basic idea is that you have a Final Fantasy style RPG where the protagonists are children on haloween and classes are replaced by costumes, each with their own special abilities. This is, on the face of it, a brilliant idea. The problem is the game consist mostly of combat, and you are actually required to fight most of the enemies in order to proceed, against a small number of enemies, using a tiny number of attacks that you use over and over again. Worse, the attacks also incorporate a timing minigame, so you can't even get through the grind it by hammering the attack button while you read a book or something, because you have to pay attention to the events in the game in order to get the timing right.
I love basic RPGs like this one.  Solid game, great animation.

Short but sweet game coming from the creative mind of Tim Schafer, who is best known for games like Grim Fandango, Psychonauts and The Secret of Monkey Island. This game is a perfect play for Halloween (and the grubbins on ice during the holiday seasons). This turn based RPG is good for all ages. During the 6 to 7 hour game you go on a quest to save your brother/sister that has been mistaken for candy by monsters. The only way you can save him/her is to go around town trick or treating, getting candy and build costumes.
i love this game so much. trick or treating, bad ♥♥♥ costumes and kicking monster ♥♥♥, what more could you ask for?

This game is so awesome, I'm spending Christmas eve and probably Christmas day playing it!

You are this little kid who's twin sister has been captured by monsters during Halloween and although you obviously hate her, you have to save her.

You collect candy which you use as coins to buy abilities to do turn-based combat against these monsters, you run around the map opening chests, completing quests, and kicking objects for candy. You trick-or-treat from door to door, you talk to  other kids running around...

I definitely recommend this game!
It's a fun little RPG-thing. And it's not even a real RPG. It's only about 8 hours, so get it when it's on sale.\nAnd try knowing nothing about it. It's more fun that way.

This was a great game with awesome Double Fine humor / artwork.  It's a fairly simplistic RPG, but had me hooked from the beginning to the end.  Everyone should buy it so they can eventually port their other games over to PC!!
A fun and cute turn based adventure with a lot to offer for the $10 price tag! Whether you're an avid rpg player or simply someone who wants to try it out, this game is a great one to own!

If you don't care about achievements this review doesn't really apply to you.

The game is OK and has some good humor (especially the Creepy Treat card names), but in all honesty it's very simple and pretty short, making it for many people just an easy achievement mine/perfect game completion... that is it would be.

Tisn't the Season" for Double Fine developers to do their jobs apparently.  Adding an achievement that is a pure gimmick like to "Play Costume Quest on Christmas" (which has a a description that in the first place is ambiguous to people in other countries that celebrate more on the 24th)
date: and which siad gimmick achievement prevents people from 100%ing the game is a slap in the face.  Many people on Mac and Linux systems are discussing this today and on Community guides so this is not an isolated occurance.  An achievement that is ostensibly only available one day in a year being broken on that day is unacceptable.  There are also reports that this has been a bug since 2012 and still hasn't been fixed.\nThe game is released for Mac

reviewText: After finishing the game 100% with all the achievments, I must say this is a good game to relax playing, funny, short, easy and rewarding. 9/10

The main game should take you about 5 hours to beat even if you're looking for absolutely every collectable, so it's pretty short, but I still really enjoyed my experience. Costume Quest is the journey of a few kids to find as much candy as they can on Halloween! It's innocent fun that conjures up a feeling of nostalgia, and gives off an aura of charm and joy. Plus, if the former doesn't hold your attention on it's own, there are a ton of innuendos and jokes that adults can connect with strewn throughout. If you're willing to let the kid inside of you out for a bit of fun, I'd say this game is worth at least one playthrough.

Quick and fun, and funny. The story is cute and satisfying. Exploring each Halloween themed level is the best part. Trick or treating gets a bit repetetive but collecting cards, candy, battle stamps, and costumes keeps it rewarding. The Grubbins On Ice addon while short is equally as enjoyable, though its Christmas vibe isnt as strong. Double Fine quality!
fun little game, dialogue is pretty funny and much collectables. Never really cared for many turn based Rpg's so I have a short attention span with them. Perfect game for Halloween time! 6/10
Sick game, bro.
coz it's cute
So cute! So addictive! A must play! <3 ^^

Costume Quest is a amazing way to have some halloween fun! If you like the idea of a game about trick or treating with quests, a system with property boosting items a.k.a. Batle Stamps, monsters, transforming costumes for a final fantasy like combat, AND CANDY! This is the perfect game for you! The story is at sometimes stupid because why would there be a medival style town right next to a carnival about colors and fun?! But if you don't worry about what's wrong with the game, it's a very fun 8 - 10 hour experience with a very cool comical art style!
Very cute and super fun. If you want a cross between Nightmare Before Christmas and Invader Zim, you should play this!

I'll be upfront.  I completely adored this game.  I love, LOVE Halloween and this game gets the atmosphere so...right.  Don't be put off by the cartoony graphics or simplistic turn based (with some QTE mixed in) combat.  Yes, there is a quite a bit of said combat and some may find it repetitive but I found the need to finish to see where it goes with their adventure far outweighing that small issue.  MSRP is $15 and I'd totally pay that but when the Double Fine bundles roll into a Steam sale it turns into a theft.

after wanting to play this game on console I finally get the chance to play it on PC I have to say in the hour or 2 i have been playing it has becoming a game I am struggling to put down the mechanics and elemens within this game are so awesome and especially for a new IP I would strongly reccomend this game to anyone even for people with not a lot of time on their hand, it has many save points, a very in depth narrative story and the battle sytem is played out so well I love the turn based aspect and am looking forward to proggressing in the story. I love the way this game looks and the theme works so well. I really enjoyed the storyline and fully got lost in the game. At times I didn't know what I was supposed to do and it was a little frustrating but overall the game was totally worth it. I'm so excited that there is a second one!

This has become my wife's favorite video game of all time, giving a new meaning to Halloween.  Gameplay is simple, with just a few mechanics that are repeated almost to the point of boredom, but the story is what really sells the game.  Everything is cartoonishly fun, down to little touches in background characters.  Quick reflexes help in combat situations, but aren't strictly essential, so even kids will be able to play.  (Those who can't or won't read might need help understanding what to do, though, particularly in the first combat.)

It's short and fairly easy to complete fully, so the replay value is limited to perhaps once a year.  Fortunately, there's a fairly obvious time of year to play it.

Oh, and yes, don't try to enter the tent in the camping store.  The multitude of waist-high fences can occasionally be annoying, but only there are they truly game-breaking.
super cute and fun! Its not challenging though so be warned mindless bashing FTW
It's about a 5 hour game and it's fun to play. I found my self beating it in one sitting.

This game is awesom as it is adorable. Imagin South Park: The Stick of Truth, only realy cute and not disgusting since of humor (not saying that South Park's humor was bad, it just isn't like that).
The story is cool and awesome where there is a plot to steal all the candy and your sibling is also being abducted during the process. in order to not get grounded you need to go and find him!
A nice turn-based combat with small RPG elements, different costumes=different attacks!
The graphics are basic but really colorful and nice.
Can't wait to play the sequal (:

Costume Quest is a game with a great atmosphere and gameplay that, while being pretty broken (load up on stuns and you can't lose), is extremely enjoyable simply to experience everything.  It's definitely an easy game, but if you're in the mood to just relax and enjoy a childlike sense of wonder again then this is the game for you.

For me, Costume Quest is the archetypal current Double Fine game. It has a great idea, nice presentation, and tedious, repetitive gameplay where you do the same thing over and over again until the designers thought it was long enough to satisfy the minimum game length people want. SomehowCostume Quest manages to distill and concentrate the absolute worst elements of JRPG design into a seemingly endless grind mitigated a little by the cute plot and presentation.

The basic idea is that you have a Final Fantasy style RPG where the protagonists are children on haloween and classes are replaced by costumes, each with their own special abilities. This is, on the face of it, a brilliant idea. The problem is the game consist mostly of combat, and you are actually required to fight most of the enemies in order to proceed, against a small number of enemies, using a tiny number of attacks that you use over and over again. Worse, the attacks also incorporate a timing minigame, so you can't even get through the grind it by hammering the attack button while you read a book or something, because you have to pay attention to the events in the game in order to get the timing right.

With a lot of charm and humor, this is a really sweet game. I've enjoyed it immensely, even though it is very short. If you're looking for a fun game that won't devour a lot of your time, try this one for a good time.

THIS GAME IS AWESOME SERIOUSLY  the costumes are good u can  even use them outside of battle, i would reccomend this to anyone and it's also addicting, this game is better than most 2-3 year old games. U CAN TRUST ME ON THAT

Recommended for those who want a lighthearted RPG. The game, including the expansion, only takes 5-6 hours to beat.
It took a while to get used to the timing-based attacks but visuals are amazing. As someone who loves halloween, I could just walk around the environments forever. Looking forward to the sequel!

When two twins end up getting separated on a Halloween night due to a mysterious invasion of candy-hogging trolls and their wicked witch leader, it is up to you to reunite them on a well spirited RPG-style adventure harnessing the power of vastly varied classic Halloween costumes!

The story has a cute enough heart to it as it is, but I feel the short length left out *a lot* of potential such as more character development, also with the theme of Halloween and the obvious influence of Nintendo's Mother/Earthbound-titles, I couldn't help but feel like the tale could've been spicier with a little more daring, genuinely frightening moments. The all around atmosphere still holds up well in the graphics, cute character design and the fitting soundtrack.

The costumes were fun, in both putting together via finding the necessary items and just plain seeing them in action during the turn-based battles, their own limit-attacks especially! When not fighting you spend your time searching for either candy, treasure-coffins, sidequests or the occasional minigame, all of which are also classic RPG features and were splendidly Halloween themed, but even during such short run some of them began feeling a bit repetitive. Trick-or-treating around the field was an exciting way to either treat yourself to most of your candy or get tricked into an enemy encounter!

All in all it doesn't take too much (or enough, more fittingly) of your time and is slightly flawed, but still had me and will surely have any other RPG and Halloween lover invested all the way!

I've heard that the designers wanted to make this like playing through a Pixar movie, and it really shows.  It's got a charming and whimsical atmosphere that makes you feel like a kid again, and while the barrage of timed hits can sort of be annoying, the game's forgiving enough that it rarely becomes problematic.  Besides, who wouldn't want to be in a world where you can don a few cardboard boxes and turn into a rocket-punch-firing robot?

If you are wondering whether-or-not this game lives-up to the pedigree of video game humour that Double Fine has, this should answer your question. It has an Arrested Development reference.\n\nNot a perfect game, but still worth buying imo.

The main game should take you about 5 hours to beat even if you're looking for absolutely every collectable, so it's pretty short, but I still really enjoyed my experience. Plus, if the former doesn't hold your attention on it's own, there are a ton of innuendos and jokes that adults can connect with strewn throughout. Tell me, you ever play a game called Paper Mario? Well, this game is kinda like that, only instead of playing as a plumber in a world made out of paper, you play a child during Halloween with an overactive imagination.. Or, is it in his/her mind? I suppose that is a mystery for yourself to solve.

Costume Quest is a charming, yet sadly short, turn-based RPG with an amusing story about two siblings who used to bicker with each other on a daily basis.. Until one of  them gets kidnapped, leading the other on a quest to get their sibling back, and in the process making new friends as well as learning to get along with the sibling they once disliked.

As I said, the game is kinda like Paper Mario, where there are no random battles, and combat is based on timing button presses to get the highest damage as well as reduce incoming damage. What makes it different is the game's main gimmic: Costumes.

There is a decent selection of outfits one can aquire throughout the game, some earned during the story, others by completing optional quests. Depending on the costume you and your friends wear, it'll affect how fights play out. The costume YOU wear is also important, because some outfits have abilities that'll allow you to progress or make your game easier (Such as lighting up dark paths or sneaking around in plain sight).

Of course, this game isn't just about costumes, but also trick or treating. In each chapter, you will be required to do some trick or treating in order to unlock gates. This is a rather amusing system, because behind each door lies a, of course, a trick or treat. If it is a treat, you get some free candy, which can be used to buy upgrades and abilites that can allow you to customise your style of play beyond just what costume you prefer to main. However, if you stumble across a trick, you get tossed into a simple battle. Anyone who played Paper Mario probably has a good idea how these battles work for the most part. They are quite fun, but after awhile it does get repetitive due to the simple combat system. Doesn't mean it is boring, though, because some battles really are quite engaging (and in a few cases, really hard unless you make use of a certain outfit or stamp).

At first, combat is challenging and thrilling, but as you progress in the game, it does start to get a bit anti-climatic (At least, until near the end), where you are able to effortlessly mow down anyone who crosses your path. Doesn't help that the highest you can level is up to 10, which brings up another sad thing about this game: It is short....

At first, the game will seem quite epic, your expectations probably being that it'll be a decently sized venture.. But then you reach level 10, and discover that you cannot level any further.. it is at that point that you discover that the end is near, and when I discovered this, I was a bit disappointed... I had gotten so invested that I was sad my adventure was almost over. At least the game ended with a bang, and I liked that, but it left me wanting more. Thankfully, there is a bonus adventure for those willing to brave it that are not totally satisfied.

Is this game worth checking out? I'd say so. Despite its flaws, it is a charming title that I am glad I had the pleasure to experience, even if it was a short one.

A very fun, easy and charming RPG that takes place in Halloween.

You control as a few children going from door to door to get candy, or find candy anywhere in the area, to become more powerful in order level up and to unlock more costumes(abilities). The combat is very Final Fantasy like, and as you get into combat depending on what your costume is, you become that creature/character/thing, literally!

The game has the whole cute-ish estatic to it, while also giving you the feeling of the festive feeling of Halloween, which they succeed completely. The game is very imaginative, pretty good story, good controls and some pretty awesome fight animations.

The game is pretty short though, and the combat is too easy. Like, if you have a clear idea where your keyboard keys are, or even where X Y B A on your controller is clearly ( which most gamers do ), then you will have no problem with the whole fight at all. I wish there were difficulty settings so the game would be a little more challenging.

Nevertheless, good little fun game that would play again on Halloween.

Like halloween? Like candy? Like cartoons? LIKE SUPER AWESOMLY AMAZING TRANSFORMING COSTUMES!? than Costume Quest is the game for you.

Costume Quest is an adventure RPG game where 3 kids are on a quest to defeat an evil witch that wants to steal all the candy to take to an alternate dimension to feed a giant skeleton monster and claim her place in that realm.AND DID I MENTION SUPER AWESOMLY AMAZING TRANSFORMING COSTUMES!?

Over the course of the game you travel through 3 different areas, meet 2 new party members, fight monsters, and collect candy to save your sister (or brother depending on what character you chose at the start) USING SUPER AWESOMLY AMAZING TRANSFORMING COSTUMES!

Now I am sure you are wondering about these costumes, scattered through the game are costume patters and peices and after you collect the costume pattern and all three peices of the costume you can craft it and put it on to use it in battle. When in battle you will transform into your costume (if you are dressed as a robot you will turn into a real fullsize giant robot). the battles are all about timing and pressing the right button at the right time, over 3 turns your special attack will charge up and they don't just do more damage but can do other things like shield or heal your team. Also some costumes have abilities out of battle that let you reach hidden areas or sneak past monsters.

Other great features include awesome cartoon graphics and and the extra little story Grubbins On Ice" where you help the monsters rebel against their evil leaders (P.S. I recommend playing Grubins On Ice after the main story).

Overall even though it was annoying at times trying to avoid monsters (this is so much easier with the ninja costme) and beat bosses and it was a bit short

A really cute Halloween themed adventure game with simple turn-based combat and mini-quests. This game is quite easy, but I suppose it's because it's been made with children in mind (although some of the bosses are quite challenging). The characters and costumes are really charming, and each costume has a unique ability in exploration and combat. So even though the mechanics are quite simple, you can pull out some interesting combinations of costumes and battle stamps (they grant an extra active or passive ability to a party member).\nCostume Quest may feel short, but in my opinion, it's long enough to keep you interested (took me 9-10 hours to 100% it with the Grubbins on Ice DLC). It's a relaxing game, I recommend it (even more so because it's Halloween season)

Ahh, Double Fine. A fine purveyor of interesting and atypical games. We can always count on you.

8/10 - A fun, refreshing, and original RPG with enough complexity to keep it interesting. It was rather short and might not be worth multiple playthroughs.

The battle system has similarities to Super Mario RPG, essentially using quicktime events to keep you active during combat. I would say that the game is too easy. A combination of the Egg, Rotten Egg, and 2-Ply T.P. made me effectively invincible. I would suggest the Black Cat, Pumpkin, and French Fries costumes on normal fights and the Robot, Vampire, and Unicorn for the bosses. For the DLC bosses I swapped the Robot for the Yeti.

I wanted to like this game, but unfortunately it was a bit of a let down. The main story is good enough, but the game play is boring and repetitive. Maybe if you could change the difficulty level things would have been better, but as the game stands you can defeat 90% of the monsters without using any battle stamps whatsoever. I was sick of trick or treating and all its monotony by the 2nd level. Cute game, but it's probably best left for the kiddos to play.\n\n6/10

When two twins end up getting separated on a Halloween night due to a mysterious invasion of candy-hogging trolls and their wicked witch leader, it is up to you to reunite them on a well spirited RPG-style adventure harnessing the power of vastly varied classic Halloween costumes!

The story has a cute enough heart to it as it is, but I feel the short length left out *a lot* of potential such as more character development, also with the theme of Halloween and the obvious influence of Nintendo's Mother/Earthbound-titles, I couldn't help but feel like the tale could've been spicier with a little more daring, genuinely frightening moments. The all around atmosphere still holds up well in the graphics, cute character design and the fitting soundtrack.

The costumes were fun, in both putting together via finding the necessary items and just plain seeing them in action during the turn-based battles, their own limit-attacks especially! When not fighting you spend your time searching for either candy, treasure-coffins, sidequests or the occasional minigame, all of which are also classic RPG features and were splendidly Halloween themed, but even during such short run some of them began feeling a bit repetitive. Trick-or-treating around the field was an exciting way to either treat yourself to most of your candy or get tricked into an enemy encounter!

All in all it doesn't take too much (or enough, more fittingly) of your time and is slightly flawed, but still had me and will surely have any other RPG and Halloween lover invested all the way!

A simple, yet very fun RPG made by Double Fine Productions. Not very surprising, since the company is known for making pretty fun games. Costume Quest uses a simple turn-based RPG battle system, so there isn't really any kind of learning curve to it. The story is pretty simple and not deep, but the characters are likeable. The costumes you wear decide what you fight as and what attack and special ability you have. It can be pretty fun to mess around and decide what the best team to use is. The game isn't really hard, but if you don't have a good team set up, it can be easy to lose. Even if you lose, there is no penalty or anything of that sort, which is sort of nice. If your a fan of simple turn-based RPGs, I fully recommend you try this game. (Note: If you aren't very good with quick time events using keyboard butons, I fully recommend you use a controller, preferably an Xbox 360 controller.)

If you crazy kids like Halloween and RPG games, then this would be a great game to pick up and play in a breeze! You can't go wrong with Double Fine either, since they're the indie company behind Psychonauts. This is also a good game to play if you want to experience what an RPG is like upon a smooth and easy-to-play surface for all ages!
Just..just buy this game. It's sooooooooo good. It's sublime. It's an rpg by Double Fine. Just go. Buy it. Now.

The adventure game sensibilities kept me interested between fights which are the times during which most games lose my interest. Recommended because it's one of the funniest games ever. Unfortunately, it also has one of the worst battle systems ever. Although you can change costumes (effectively classes) outside of battle, once one starts you're stuck with what you went in wearing. And that's where the problem begins. Each class only has one attack and a timed special ability, none of which are particularly interesting. Worse, because there are only two costumes in the game with healing abilities, every battle had to be designed around the possibility that the player would be totally unable to heal. The end result is that every battle is exactly the same thing whether you're fighting a boss or a basic encounter. They tried to add a bit of variation with equippable Battle Stamps. Unfortunately, you're limited to one per character, can't change in battle, and some of them are objectively better than others. They don't solve the problem.

If you're willing to put up with the awful battles for fantastic writing and some unique scenarios, it's worth the sale price of $5. I'd struggle to recommend it at much higher of a price, unfortunately, because this is a game that hits its peak early. It's a fantastic first 90 minutes, a pretty good second 90 minutes, and a third that I didn't finish because it had become primarily battles rather than laughs.

Minor note: This game has terrible mouse acceleration that can't be turned off. It doesn't affect gameplay at all, but it makes menu navigation annoying.

Do you enjoy being happy? Enjoy smiling and being filled with that warm fuzzy feeling you get after laughing for 2 and a half minutes straight? Well then you should buy this game. reviewText: It's a little slow at first but once you're used to the game (when you're in the mall) it's a lot better. It's a well balanced turn based fighter with an rpg adventure side, good visuals and well optimized. Plenty of humour too, shame there's no voice acting as it would be a very brilliant game if it had voices too.

One word to sum it up? Charming.
Costume quest is a turn-based RTS at heart and enjoyable from start to end. I honestly can't think of any con except maybe the low difficulty.
Costume Quest comes with achievements, collectibles, spells, monsters,costumes, bosses. What else does a game need in the end?
Also comes with a free DLC and the promise for more and while not trying to spoil the end, it does offer an opening for future development.
My advice, get it, buy it, play it. You won't regret it. Worth every penny.

Not the type of game I usually play but it came in Amazon's Double Fine Bundle and I gave it a go. I was very impressed despite the cartoon graphics and weird story. Controls & combat are simple and straight forward but the abundance of costumes adds a lot of variety. Definitely has some good humor and is still safe for kids.\n\nHighly recommend using a controller but it has to be Xinput or you need to use x360ce. Very short, 6 1/2 hours to beat game & DLC but the length just kind of feels right for the game.

Costume Quest is incredibly adorable. Although it took an extra year to get it from the consoles to the PC, I don't think anything was lost in the transition. Heck, it comes with the DLC, too!

Gameplay's kind of a little repetative; you trick or treat, you kill some Gomoblins, do some puzzlin' here and there, sometimes there's a boss fight. There isn't much to break up the formula, but it works well enough on its own.

What stood out to me was how charming the game itself is. It's very much a trip back to childhood, with memories of homemade box robots or giant-headed felt unicorns. It's really cute and to me one of it's big selling points.

If you have any sort of childhood nostalgia, this will be a game for you.
Easily one of the most charming games I've ever played. Well worth the price of admission.

The writing, characters, and story in CQ is what draws you in and keeps you in. The gameplay/combat is very interesting at first, but after maybe halfway through the game, I stumbled on a method of conducting battles that had a very rinse & repeat feeling to it. You may not experience it, and it can easily be avoided simply through player choice, so I wont harp on that too much, but the combat is the game's weakest point. It's a fun little ride and well worth it at any price.\n\n4/5

This game brings back the feeling of childhood wonder like few games can. Mechanically, half of Costume Quest falls firmly into the JRPG genre with a very simple battle system and overworld exploration where you open chests and talk to people and fight monsters and bosses.

The other half is basically an adventure game. Each costume your kids can wear has its own abilities both in and out of combat, and the non-combat abilities will be crucial to solving the environmental puzzles your team will run into throughout the game.

Both halves of the game are excellent and easy to learn, and the magic of Halloween is fully preserved in the game's environments and presentation. Play it!

As one of two twins, who are new in town, you set out into the Halloween night to trick-or-treat your neighbours - just to find your sibling abducted by REAL monsters! And, 'cause it's Halloween, no adults realize it's real monsters. Collect candy, trading cards, costumes and explore three rich and exciting areas to rescue your sibling, before your parents get all up in yo biz.

So, now down to brass tacks. Is it any good? Well. The graphic style of this adventure RPG is stunning, the level design is flawless, the gameplay is great fun and the battlesystem is thought through. Sure, the battles can be quite monotone in the last half hour of the game, but it's manageable due to exciting skill tree choices; your skills in battle change depending on what costume you have one. The achievement are challenging but manageable, which makes the game replayable. It's an hommage to the imagination of kids and to Halloween. I really recommend it.
